div.head:
Embleme 12. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The Stone, which Saturne vomited up, being devoured instead
of his sonne jupiter, is placed in Helicon as a monument to men.

lg.l: Know would you why the poets soe recount
The fame of Helicon, the Muses mount?
That monumentall stone is plac'd thereon,
Which Saturne gorg'd instead of Jove his sonne.
Be wise, the sense agrees not wish the sound,
For Saturn's stone in Chymistrys found.

div.head: Discourse 12.
div.ab:
The Allegory of Saturne wee find to be taken divers wayes: for the Astro
nomers repute him the highest of the planetts in order; the young students
of Chymistry the meanest of metalls, namely lead: The heathen poets: con
ceivd him to be the father of Jupiter, sonne of Caelum; the Mythologists time.
But though all these may seem to have thought aright in their sense, yet
they will not declare those things which are elswhere spoken of Saturne,
why hee devoured and vomited up his sonns, and a stone instead of Jupiter,
why hee is the discoverer of truth, why appearing with a sieth, a serpent,
blacknesse, morosity, and distorted feet? Herein the last thinke themselves to
interpret best, saying, that time revealed and manifests truth, slided away as a Ser
pent, cuts all things downe with death as by a sieth, devoured its children, that is,
all those things which it hath generated, digests hard stones, or cannot consume
them, and therefore dos as it were vomit them up againe: These things doe indeed
agree in part, but are not consonant to the truth of the thing, and all circum
stances. But the exercises Philosophers doe say, that Saturne is first in their
worke, which if hee be really praesent, they cannot erre, truth is discovered in
darknesse; but there is nothing besides blacknesse: wherefore they say in
Turba Philosophorum, whatsoever colour comes after blacknesse is laudable:
and when you see your matter blacke, rejoyce, because it is the begining of
the worke: And, when it is first blacke, wee say it is the key of the worke,
because it is not effected without blacknesse, as the Rosary hath it, with Arnold,
and the Speculum: when you are operating, endeavour to obtaine first a
blacke colour, and then will you be certaine that you putrefy, and process
the right way. And a little after: that blacknesse is called earth, which is made
by light decoction soe often repeated, till blacknesse be most eminent. For
this reason say the same, that Saturne possesseth the earth, Mercury water,
Jupiter aire, Sol fire. Saturne therefore is blacknesse, the discoverer of truth,
who followes a stone instead of Jupiter. For blacknesse, that is, a darke cloud
covers the stone as first, that is cannot be seen: Therefore sayth Morienes
every body without a soule is darke and obscure: And Hermes: Take his head
dissolve it with the Sharpest vinegar, or the vine of children, till it be made
darke: This being performed hee lines in putrefaction, and the darke clouds which
were upon him, and in his body, before hee dyed, are returned. This stone is
againe disgorged by Saturne, when it becomes white, and then is it sett upon
the top of Helicon for a monument to men, as Hesiod writes: for whitenesse is
really comprehended under blacknesse, which is drawne out of its bowells, that
out of the stomacke of Saturne. therefore sayth Democritus; putrify Tinne
with a peculiar ablution, draw its blacknesse and obscurity from it, and the
whitenesse of it will appear. And in Turba it is sayd: Joyne the dry with
the moist, that is, the blacke earth with its water, and coct, till it be whitened.
This Arnold in Novum lumen chapt. 4. excellently declares, saying; That
moisture therefore which caused blacknesse in decoction, Shews itselfe to be
dryed, when the white colour begins to appear. And a little after: And
my Master sayd to mee, that that brunity ascended, because the whitenesse
Discourse 12.
was drawne out of the belly of its blacknesse, as is sayd in Turba: For when
you see it blacke know that the whitenesse of it is hidden in the bowells of the
blacknesse first appearing: As the same blacknesse is called Saturne, soe allso
Lead: Thereupon sayth Agadimon in Turba: Coct your brasse, till the blacknesse come forth,
which they call money, and mix the matters of your art, and you will find blacknesse
presently, which is the Philosophers lead, of which they have treated much in their
books: Hitherto relates the saying of Emigamy, that the splendor of Saturne ascending
into the aire appears noe otherwise than darkened. And of Plato in the Rosary; The
first way of governing Saturne is to putrefy and put it upon Sol: by which it is evident
that the sense of the Philosophers, speaking of Saturne, is farre different from the
comon acceptation. This Saturne generates Jupiter, that is, an obscure whitenesse, Jupiter
of Latona Diana, that is perfect whitenesse, and Apollo, that is, rednesse; and this is
the successive mutation of all perfect colours: This Stone cast out by Saturne is
reported to be placed at the top of the mountaine as a monument to men, which
is a thing most true
